The leak detection and alarm systems are located at the following locations:

  * Harris Field WTP chlorine storage area
  * Tennessee Road Pump Station chlorine storage area

The leak detection system activates audio and visual alarms when a chlorine concentration of 1 parts per million (ppm) or higher is detected.  When the chlorine alarms are engaged, personnel are restricted from entering the chlorine area without the appropriate personnel protective equipment.  

A perimeter fence and locked gates surround the Harris Field WTP and Tennessee Road Pump Station.

4. SUMMARY OF THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Harris Field WTP accidental release prevention program includes the following key elements:

  * Detailed management system.
  * Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.
  * Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.
  * Performance of process hazard analysis (PHA) of chlorine system, with operation and maintenance staff participation and review, 
    and trained PHA facilitator.
  * Chlorine system SOPs, written by the operations staff.  
  * Training of plant operators in chlorine system SOPs.
  * Training of maintenance staff in chlorine system maintenance program.
  * Implementation of an incident investigation program.
  * Availability of personal protective equipment, including SCBA.
  * Training of WTP staff relative to awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine and presence of chlorine 
        detectors and alarms

d, and chemical 
    exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine.  This information includes chlorine background 
    information and safety data sheets (SDSs), along with process and chemical safety information.
  * Specifications for the chlorine process are collected and provided in one place for easy reference.  Details such as maximum 
    intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; safe upper and lower pressures; and codes and standards used to design, 
    build, and operate the processes are on file at the City of Homestead's Wittkop Park WTP and Wastewater Treatment Plant.

5. PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

The PHA was updated in September 2020.  Recommendations resulting from the 2020 PHA are in the process of being evaluated and/or implemented.

6. INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

The Harris Field WTP investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in injury to personnel, injury to the public, damage to the environment, or property damage so that similar accidents can be prevented.  An investigation team will be assembled, and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are evaluated, and appropriate recommendations are implemented.  Information found during the investigation is reviewed by affected staff and used as needed to revise operation and maintenance procedures.

7. STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES

The Harris Field WTP has prepared written SOPs for the chlorine system.  Written SOPs include: startup, normal operation, emergency shutdown, startup after emergency shutdown, ordering 1-ton chlorine containers, 1-ton chlorine container delivery, and 1-ton chlorine containers connection.  The SOPs are annually reviewed by the Superintendent Water and Wastewater Treatment to confirm that they are current and accurate.

8. MECHANICAL INTEGRITY AND MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

The Harris Field WTP has a comprehensive m

echanical integrity program.  The chlorine system receives regular preventive maintenance based on the manufacturer's recommendation.  Additionally, the Harris Field WTP has a management of change (MoC) policy to ensure that all changes to the chlorine system are properly documented.  Employees involved in operating and maintaining the chlorine process whose job tasks will be affected by the change shall be informed of, and trained in, the change prior to startup.

9. PRE-STARTUP REVIEW

The Harris Field WTP has procedures in place to ensure that a pre-startup safety review is conducted prior to starting up a new covered process or after a shutdown event, or prior to starting up modifications to the chlorine process that require implementation of the MoC procedure.

10. TRAINING

Harris Field WTP employees presently involved in operating and maintaining the chlorine system are trained in the chlorine process and the applicable operation and maintenance procedures.  The City of Homestead ensures that each employee newly assigned to the chlorine process is trained and tested to be competent in the process safety management, SOPs, consequences of deviation from the SOPs, and chlorine process safety features.  All employees involved in operating and maintaining the chlorine system have been trained in the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out their duties and responsibilities.  

Management personnel are trained on process safety management and compliance with federal and state regulations pertaining to risk management planning and process safety management.  All on-site facility personnel that are not involved directly with the chlorine system are also trained in process safety management, emergency evacuation, and the Emergency Action Plan.

Process safety management refresher training is provided annually to each employee operating the covered process, management personnel, and employees assigned to the facility to ensure that the

employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.  The City of Homestead retains records of initial and refresher training, and provides certification of the records, which includes the identity of the employee, the date of training, and the signature of the person(s) administering the training.

11. CONTRACTORS

The City of Homestead has procedures and policies in place that specify the information required to be provided to the contractors performing work on the chlorination process, the training requirements for contractor employees, and mechanisms to obtain assurance from contractors that they have informed their employees of the appropriate safety rules.  The City of Homestead is required to provide information and explanations concerning the hazards and processes and to obtain and evaluate information regarding the contractor's safety program.

12. INTERNAL COMPLIANCE AUDITS

Internal compliance audits will be conducted every three years to verify compliance with the programs and procedures contained in the RMP.  The City of Homestead will assemble an audit team that will include personnel knowledgeable in the RMP rule and in the chlorine process.  This team will evaluate whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of the RMP rule and whether the prevention program is sufficient to help ensure safe operation of the process.  The results of the audit will be documented, recommendations evaluated, and appropriate enhancements to the prevention program will be implemented.

13. HOT WORK PERMIT

The Harris Field WTP requires that employees and contractors employ safe work practices when performing hot work in, on, or around the chlorine process.  The Harris Field WTP uses a permitting program to ensure that hot work is conducted safely on, or near a process involving chlorine.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1. INTRODUCTION

At the beginning of the 1900s water-borne diseases were a leading cause of death in the United States (U.S.).  Epidemics of typhoid, cholera, dysentery and other water-borne diseases occurred.  After chlorine's introduction into public water supplies, deaths from typhoid in the U.S. dropped dramatically from 25,000 in 1900 to less than 20 in 1960.  Water-borne disease is even still a leading cause of infant mortality in many countries throughout Asia, Africa, and Latin America where infant mortality rates are 10 to 20 times greater than in the U.S.  In the U.S., however, water-borne disease has been virtually eliminated due to an effective public health strategy of utilizing chlorine for drinking water disinfection.  Chlorine disinfection is arguably one of the greatest achievements for public health worldwide in the last hundred years and is credited with increasing the life expectancy of Americans by more than 50 percent.

The use of chlorine is not risk free, however.  Historically it is clear that utilities have recognized the risks and have been successful in developing procedures to handle chlorine safely and to protect the off-site public and the environment from potential accidental releases.

As an added layer of protection, the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) promulgated the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule in volume 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) part 68.  The goal of these regulations is to reduce the risk to employees, the public, and the environment by preventing the accidental release of hazardous chemicals.  The City of Homestead Harris Field Water Treatment Plant (WTP) is regulated because it stores chlorine above the threshold quantity defined in these regulations. The Harris Field WTP includes a chlorine system located at Well No. 5 (referred to as the Tennessee Road Pump Station) and a chlorine system at Well No. 6 (located near the water storage tower). 15. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM SUMMARY

A comprehensive emergency response program has been prepared which outlines the procedures and lines of communication that are necessary to effectively respond to and mitigate a potential chlorine gas release.  The City of Homestead Public Works and Engineering Department personnel do not have the specialized equipment or training to respond to a major release. Therefore, this program focuses on procedures to identify chemical releases, safely evacuate plant personnel, and notify the local emergency responders (fire, police, and hazardous materials [HAZMAT] team) who are responsible for implementing the incident command system (ICS) and coordinating all response actions.

The Harris Field WTP is equipped with automatic vacuum shutoff regulators which prevent accidental release of gases if vacuum is lost. The facility emergency response program includes procedures for notifying the local HAZMAT teams of the incident and procedures for evacuating the facility.  There are local HAZMAT teams in Miami-Dade County that can respond to and mitigate a chlorine leak. Facility staff have coordinated with the local HAZMAT team and Fire Department to ensure that they are fully trained and equipped to quickly respond to an incident.

16. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The RMP Program Level 3 regulations are similar to the requirements of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management Program (PSMP) rule in volume 29 CFR § 1910.119.  Although Florida public sector employees are not covered by federal OSHA regulations, Miami-Dade County Administrative Order 7-14 requires compliance with OSHA regulations. 

The Harris Field WTP has always understood the risks associated with chlorine and has maintained a well-trained staff and a safely operated and maintained facility.  The Harris Field WTP's track record is exemplary with respect to handling hazardous chemicals.  Furthermore, the Harris Field WTP has taken a comprehensive approach to be in full compliance with the RMP and PSMP regulations.

The key element of complying with the RMP and PSMP rules is development of policies, operating procedures, maintenance programs, and emergency response program to ensure the safety of employees and the public.  The City of Homestead is committed to providing a safe and healthy work environment to its employees and protecting the public, on-site and off-site property, and the environment from releases of chlorine.  Hence, the City of Homestead has prepared a comprehensive Program Level 3 RMP.  This Executive Summary briefly describes the following key elements of the Harris Field WTP RMP:

  * Accidental release prevention and emergency response polices
  * General facility and regulated substance information
  * Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific  preventive steps
  * Five-year accident history summary
  * Emergency response program summary
  * Planned changes, if any, to improve safety

2. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The City of Homestead's accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates proven chlorine process technology and safety systems,

incorporates staff training, provides detailed information on the hazards of chlorine and process safety management, implements operational and maintenance standard operating procedures (SOPs), trains and plans for emergency response and emergency actions, includes contractor safety, and uses tested and proven management system practices.

3. GENERAL FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE INFORMATION

The City of Homestead owns and operates the Harris Field WTP.  The facility's mission is to protect public health by providing safe drinking water.  The Harris Field WTP is located at 675 North Homestead Boulevard, Homestead, Florida 33030.  The Harris Field WTP is located in Harris Field Park which is bounded by North Homestead Boulevard (a.k.a, US 1) to the east, Campbell Drive to the north, Northeast 12th Avenue (a.k.a., Tennessee Road) to the east, and by Cocowalk Estates to the south.  

The Harris Field WTP stores chlorine which is a regulated toxic substance under the RMP rule. The chlorine systems at the Harris Field WTP and Tennessee Road Pump Station provide chlorine to the water to maintain required disinfection levels for drinking water.  The maximum quantity of chlorine present at the Harris Field WTP at any given time exceeds the listed threshold quantity in the RMP rule.  

Chlorine is delivered in 1-ton cylinders to the chlorine storage area.  The cylinders contain chlorine gas that has been liquified under pressure.  The chlorine gas is drawn at a vacuum through polyvinyl chloride (PVC) vacuum lines to the injectors which feed chlorine into the water.  

The Harris Field WTP and Tennessee Road Pump Station chlorine systems are provided with a number of safety features to protect the employees and the surrounding community.  Safety features include leak detection systems, alarms, and automatic shutdown systems.  The chlorine systems inject chlorine into the water by use of vacuum feed through vacuum regulators.
